direction.raw_text: Most of the men are clustered around their bunks, and in the dull light we see some of them in the aisles, talking, playing cards... while most of the others are whistling, clapping, and laughing as Uhlmann does his silly little clog dance... it is apparent the ugly episode between Galt and Uhlmann has been forgotten for the moment. The lights are hung from cords down off the ceiling and for a complex this size it could use ten... there are but two. Uhlmann is having the time of his ignorant life... the more the men applaud, the more he "clog dances".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - LUDWIG AND ADOLF They are both seated on their top bunk, Adolf enjoying the poor dance Uhlmann is giving as Ludwig looks down the aisle towards Helmut's bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks like Helmut found some new ears to listen to his Super Star fantasies... Adolf takes a look, shrugs his shoulder, as if to say I couldn't care less... and goes on watching the action of Uhlmann and the other men...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ringling Brothers would have done anything for me to appear with them but I had to do what was best for me!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself, but for Adolf to hear as well; a la Shakespeare, mimicking Helmut)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The four new men are surrounding Helmut on the top of his bunk listening to his bragging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I told Mr. Ringling if he wanted "Helmut" he'd have to bring his circus to Germany... I am a German, I told him, and my responsibility is to my own people who are my biggest fans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you really say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I did... they offered me anything...  anything I wanted to go with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey! I saw the circus in Berlin about four years ago...  Didn't  you make your entrance in a long tail coat with a pair of tails on the jacket about fifty feet long?  Sure!  And a funny Little clown at the very end carrying the tails like a woman's train? Helmut studies the prisoners glare and decides he couldn't even remember the clown he saw was Gustav the Great, why not?  No one would ever know... and he nods with a kind of studied humility... yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were great! Helmut eats it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should have seen him... You'd never know it was him... with the long tails  and white tie... red nose...  long hair...  and a battered top hat... with the hair hanging way down to his shoulders...  and, ah, let me see... oh, yeah... your mouth went from ear to ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do "clowns" ever come up with such ideas for faces and make-up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't happen overnight... it takes years and years... You try many faces, then finally you hit the one that's just right for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My kids will never believe this, I can't wait to... tell... His voice trails off as he realizes the hopelessness of what he was about to say.  This puts a damper on the discussion and the men start to break up and get down off the bunk. Helmut, seeing his captive audience leaving... panics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait, let me tell you some other things...  I mean things that are really exciting and...  please! Please... let me just have a few more...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on with those guys? He's looking off down the aisle where Uhlmann has his audience... The four prisoners move out into the aisle to get a better look, leaving Helmut perched on his bunk with a pleading and broken look of despair...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you know "clowns" literally bequeath their faces to their sons, or sometimes to... He realizes it's futile as the four new prisoners move towards Uhlmann and the others down the aisle...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, let's see what's such fun... He moves and the others move along with him.  Helmut thinks about joining them, and starts to move off his bunk but his body won't respond... he just hangs there limply... his head lowered, a sad man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING OVER the men placing Helmut in the very deep  b.g. as we see the four new prisoners walk over to watch the action...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE - UHLMANN, GALT, KELTNER, AND OTHERS Uhlmann is just finishing his dance with a spin, when he finally gets dizzy and topples over on one of the bunks. All the men applaud wildly.  Uhlmann laying half down and half up on the lower bunk he landed on, breathing heavily... yells over to Galt...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Galt, it's your turn, how about doin' one of your belly dances for us? All the men agree and start yelling for Galt to do it... Galt moves out into the center of the aisle in the clearing made by the men, and holds up his hands for silence... they quiet down and Galt looks around until he spots Keltner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reverend? The men become very still, they look from Galt to Keltner and back to Galt, their eyes reflecting suspicion of him, wondering what he's up to now.  Galt is fully aware of this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Reverend, what do you think? Would a little belly-dancing be too much for the boys? Keltner studies Galt for a beat, then accepts his offer of a truce.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little fun is what we need... so... if you'll all hold the noise down, I'll join in. A hushed cheer goes up from the men as Keltner stands besides Galt.  Galt holds his hands over his head and nods for Keltner to do the same thing.  The Reverend does, and now Galt begins undulating his hips.  Keltner studies the move for a beat and then does the same thing but with comical awkwardness. Franz starts playing a slow sensuous rhythm on his harmonica. The men clap and whistle softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is sitting upright on top of his bunk, watching what Galt has Keltner doing, a look of disgust passes his face as he turns away from what he'd been watching and gets busy with his papers and figuring again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are just finishing their dance.  The men applaud wildly but softly... Keltner, puffing, moves over to the side and sits on one of the bunks to catch his breath.  Galt takes a few bows, and the men react with applause and whistling that's beginning to take on "noise" proportions... Keltner motions for the men to hold it down... and they do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say, why don't we get the clown to do something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A clown?  Who's a clown??
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've heard of "Helmut Doork". That's him down there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't waste your time.  You'll never get the Great Doork to do anything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he starts walking towards Helmut's bunk...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'm sure he will! The others follow right behind.  There is a look on Keltner's face like he would like to stop them, but between his puffing and his certainty that Helmut will be alright, he stays where he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he walks with the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're wasting your time.  He doesn't perform for the likes of us... he'll turn you down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right, we've been asking him for three years...  I have a feeling he only does his little routines for the crowned heads of Europe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, of course, the BIG heads of Berlin. There is general laughter... as the group arrives at Helmut's bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees something's going to happen, he puts his papers away and sits upright... waiting... his eyes catch Galt's eyes peering at him. Galt tells it all with his eyes... This one isn't "sacred" to the men... he might just be the pigeon Galt's been hoping for... the one every bully looks for, for his own brand of fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about it, Doork?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to, but I can't... really... I can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't?  Did I hear you say you can't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to do something... but... (pointing to the 2nd New Prisoner) He can tell you... He's seen me work...  I need props... make-up... I work with a lot of different things...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right... I did... and he does!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, tell them... I can't just do anything...  I need lights, props, my costume. Galt doesn't like no for an answer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, me and these... gentlemen... we don't expect you to do your "act", just a little something that'll give us a laugh, that's all. Keltner moves in from o.s. and stands at the back of the group watching and listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, forget it... and that's probably his problem...  he's forgotten how!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute, you guys... show people have to be in a mood... (to Franz) Play a little music, like in a circus... Franz starts playing his harmonica... slowly...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There!  Ain't that nice?  Don't it put you in a mood?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (swinging his legs around ready to jump down)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it stops him in his tracks; he stays up on the bunk)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: !  I need things to do my act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Doork, what about that drunk routine... that was funny... Helmut looks at him puzzled... he can't think or remember anything at this point... certainly not anything relating to any of the previous lies he's told...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, that drunk thing...  that does sound funny...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I still need many things... props and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't remember you using anything in that drunk routine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey... are you trying to fool us? With this Keltner moves in and up to Galt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave him alone!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay out of this, Reverend. We're not doing anything... We just want him to join in the fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right!  If a Reverend can give us a laugh, why not a clown? All the men ad lib their agreement with what Uhlmann just said; it appears that they are all on Galt's side, and Keltner knows it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't have to be anything special... a little dance, maybe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like that disgusting exhibition you did?  Oh, no... not me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, Doork, so I can tell my kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't you get it through your heads, I need...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: need you to give us a laugh. Galt grabs Helmut's jacket and pulls him off the bunk, nose to nose to him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... TRY! Galt has Helmut by the neck portion of the jacket, practically choking him to death... his vice-like hands are closing in on his throat and Helmut's trying vainly just to breathe... One of the prisoners starts pounding his feet and making a march-like noise yelling from the other end... "So try!"... "So try!"... "So try!"... "So try!"... the other prisoners in the barracks pick up the chant and the stomping... Keltner doesn't even hear the racket they've started because of his concern for Helmut being choked to death... He tries to loosen Galt's hands from Helmut's throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough, leave him alone!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay out of it, Reverend! Galt spins Helmut around so that his back is facing the aisle and he walks him into the center area... the other men feeling this violence happening, and watching.  Helmut being choked, triggers all of their venom and their hate and they really come on strong... stomping, yelling...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Choke him harder...  see if that's funny!  Make him dance! Hey, Doork!... be funny now! He don't look so funny to me!  He sure as hell looks funny to me!  Hey, Galt, pull his string and make the dummy funny! And they stomp and they stomp and they stomp... "So try!"... "So try!"... They get louder and louder... Helmut is kicking his legs, which are off the ground, and Galt won't let go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face is turning color... he hasn't a lot of air left in his lungs... and Keltner is practically hanging onto Galt trying to get his hands loose... and Galt could carry another three men without batting an eye.  Galt puts him down slowly, in the middle of the aisle, so that just his feet touch the ground, but he keeps his hands around his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your public is calling, clown... now, clown!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING OVER Galt, Keltner and Helmut, we see the door of the barracks slam open and bang against the wall making more noise than anything all the men made together, and they all freeze...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE - THE GUARD He stands in the doorway, legs spread apart, hands on his waist... and he is wearing a raincoat, the barracks has become totally silent... all that is heard is the rain pecking away on the roof.  Galt has let go of Helmut who just lays on the floor with Galt and Keltner on both sides of him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is going on here? (to Helmut) On your feet! Helmut gets up, dizzily, just about getting oxygen back into his system...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was showing us some of his funny clown falls... The Guard surveys the faces of the others as they stare back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of all the noise coming from in here -- I have been called up front to explain...  I don't like to be called up front...  I don't like to have to explain... (menacingly) And, you might not like it, either. (a beat) Back to your bunks, all of you... Turn out the lights, and keep it QUIET ! As the guard turns to the door to go, Helmut takes a step forward about to stop the guard, Keltner grabs his arm and turns him the other way... the Guard exits closing the door, quietly behind him... The men start to disperse... Galt gives Helmut a "I'll get you for this" look and returns to his own bunk with Uhlmann almost up his ass following... Keltner leads Helmut back to their bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was just going to ask him about the forms... my release...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was not the time, believe me! Keltner sits Helmut down next to him on his lower bunk, as Helmut rubs his throat, and tries swallowing a few times...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurt much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I'm alright... thank you. They both sit in silence... Helmut breaks the silence...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johann, why do they pick on me? I've never done anything to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've never done anything for them! Helmut dislikes Keltner's remark and gets up from the lower bunk and starts up to his.  He gets to the top bunk and starts to get onto it, stops and whispers to Keltner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think I should have performed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men would have appreciated it. Helmut rolls into his bunk, the lights go out and he lies on his back staring at the ceiling.  Keltner sits on the side of his bunk and takes his shoes off... periodically the rays from the searchlights revolving outside cross the windows to momentarily flood the barracks with light.  After a few seconds, Helmut leans over to whisper to Keltner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johann!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't believe me, do they?  I mean about being a clown?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'd say you've convinced most. However -- (a long beat) There is one you haven't convinced... Helmut stares at Keltner, knowing full well what's coming... yet doesn't have the courage to take the chance that it might be another thought... so he waits...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, Helmut... you!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (he stands up, eye level with Helmut)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The truth of Keltner's charge hits Helmut with an overpowering force.  He looks at Keltner for a beat... his eyes filled with pain, then slowly turns away from him, leaving him standing there as we PAN with Helmut and HOLD on...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rain is pouring down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the next morning, a chilly, damp day following a night of rain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attention!  Attention!  All prisoners will assemble immediately in the yard.  All prisoners will assemble immediately in the yard. Attention! Attention! The loudspeakers repeat the command.  Across the muddy, puddle splotched yard, a barbed wire barricade about six feet high has been erected, dividing the camp in two.  A number of guards patrol the fence on both sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uhlmann is looking out into the yard.  He motions to someone to "take a look at this".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galt has just arrived at the window where Uhlmann is standing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They've put up barbed wire!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other in wonder as they start into the aisle.  The men in the barracks are frantically trying to organize themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The prisoners are pouring out of the barracks doorway.  Galt and Uhlmann are already standing outside as Helmut, Keltner, Herman, Adolf, Franz, Ludwig, Stout Prisoner, New Prisoners, join them.  All look o.s. momentarily speechless at what they see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell... ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PRISONERS' POV Beyond the fence we see men, women and children standing in groups near the barracks on that side of the camp.  The SOUND of children crying can be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they quickly scurry to line up in front of their own hut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Youngsters!  They've got youngsters over there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Women!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another fence!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FAVORING KELTNER Helmut stands next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does it mean?  What do they need a fence for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Misery loves company.  Looks like they're going to deny us even that. The Guard is shoving the late-comers into place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right.  All right, move.  Hurry it up.  Move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING ACROSS the prisoners in f.g. toward the new fence. Guards move among the men, herding them into lines.  On the other side of the fence, we can see the new arrivals lining up, being prodded into place by Guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On both sides of the fence, the prison inmates have assembled in the wet, forbidden yard.  On one side are the regular prisoners, who watch the guards warily as they straighten their lines.  On the other side are the new prisoners -- about two hundred frightened Jews of all ages, including thirty or forty children and a number of very old men and women.  They stand in absolute silence as the loudspeakers blare again, except for the crying children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attention!  The Commandant issues the following special order:  the north side of the camp is now temporary quarters for non-Aryan prisoners.  Fraternizing between Aryan and non-Aryan prisoners is strictly prohibited.  Any violation of this order will be severely punished.  Heil Hitler... Repeating...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING THROUGH the booted, outspread legs of a soldier guard in f.g. toward the line of prisoners behind him.  One woman holds a child of about three who cries inconsolably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commandant issues the following special order: As the announcement is read, the guard's legs turn around, and he walks away from the CAMERA toward the woman.  He stands before her menacingly, and she clutches the child closer to her in a futile attempt to hush its crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The north side of the camp is now temporary quarters for non-Aryan prisoners.  Fraternizing between Aryan and non-Aryan prisoners is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: along line of prisoners from barracks H to show their various reactions as the announcement continues -- disdain, surprise, sympathy and relief.  The guard stands with his back to the line at the end farthest from the CAMERA. Galt is near the CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jews! Prisoners nearest to Galt eye him questioningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... strictly prohibited.  Any violation of this order will be severely punished.  Heil Hitler. The loudspeakers go dead.  The prisoners stand silently studying the new arrivals across the yard.  The new prisoners self-consciously file back into their huts on the other side of the fence.  As the prisoners begin to break rank -- GUARD Prisoners from barracks H remain in line.  Barracks H will remain in line. The prisoners turn and look in direction of the Guard as they straighten their lines.  The guard paces slowly along the line inspecting it silently.  On the fringes of the scene, we can see prisoners from other barracks gathering to see what their fellow convicts are in for.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CLOSE SHOT - GUARD Finally he stops and contemplates his shabby charges with disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said last night I didn't think I would enjoy being called up to account for the noise coming from barracks H.  I can tell you this morning I didn't enjoy it. He walks down the line, looking at each man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what caused the trouble last night, but I'm not blaming you entirely. (fatherly) I failed you.  I should have seen that you all have much too much energy for the confined life you lead here. (he smiles benevolently)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to correct that.  I've been told that energy comes from food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their faces reflect that they know what is coming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING PAST the line of prisoners in f.g. to the Guard, who has paused to let his words sink in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So... to help you... all rations are canceled for the next... forty-eight hours. A hushed ripple of ad lib grumbling and growling rolls along the line of prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, if that doesn't quiet you down, I'll think of some other ideas you'll like even less. I'm going to make this barracks the quietest in the camp. (roaring) Is that clear? The prisoners are silent but their faces register their resentment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, don't blame me. (with sly meaning) I didn't start the trouble last night. The truth of what he has said is reflected in the faces of the men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fall out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they stand with the other prisoners, watching the guard move off.  Keltner looks worried, the others are angry, Helmut seems undecided as his eyes follow the guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bastard!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't go without food. I'll starve. Suddenly Helmut makes up his mind and starts off after the Guard.  Keltner, sensing the mood of the men, puts a restraining hand on his arm, whispers to him hoarsely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut, don't. But Helmut shakes him off and hurries away. The other prisoners notice where he is headed and exchange looks.  Keltner shakes his head.  Galt's eyes narrow as he watches Helmut run off after the guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's the one we can thank for the diet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MOVING The CAMERA MOVES BACKWARD as the Guard strides toward it, his face sour.  Behind him we can see Helmut running to catch up to him.  When he is close enough...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir?  Corporal... The guard stops and turns so abruptly that Helmut almost runs into him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork.  Helmut Doork.  Remember? The papers... You said... Remember the special forms for the Gestapo to review my case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No papers. He stalks off.  Helmut starts to say something more but thinks better of it.  Crushed, he starts back towards his barracks, head down.  He walks sadly for several steps, then looks up and stops, his expression changing to one of uneasiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV A dozen of Helmut's barracks-mates, including Galt, Uhlmann, Adolf, Ludwig, Herman, the Stout Prisoner, several of the New Prisoners, are drifting across the yard towards him, and the looks on many faces bode no good for Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The men converge and form a half circle around him. As the men close in on him, he moves back until we cna see the barbed wire fence behind him.  Helmut senses their disposition and remains warily silent.  Keltner and Franz stand slightly behind the pack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you say now, Mr. Doork, Almighty! (to men) Last night he wouldn't give us a laugh.  Today they won't give us food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What were you doing?  Making a deal with your guard pal to slip you some food?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!  I was asking him about the forms he'd promised to get me. (admonishing) Because of last night... I'm not getting them. Keltner, seeing how disappointed Helmut is, moves up through the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When this blows over, Helmut, we'll...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't feel sorry for him.  He's got no one to blame but himself.  The whole thing was his doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's been telling us how great he is; how funny.  Why?  Why couldn't he have done a trick or two for us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Reverend did a turn.  What's so special about him? The men voice agreement... Helmut should have performed. Helmut starts to go around one end of the semi-circle but the men bar his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't start anything here.  We're in enough trouble. The other prisoners in the b.g., those who have remained in the yard to see what was going to happen to the men of barracks H, sense trouble, the kind they want no part of, and begin scurrying back to their own barracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not starting anything, we're finishing something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've decided Doork here is going to keep us laughing so hard we won't be able to hear our stomachs growling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Better hurry it up, clown.  'Cause my stomach's growling already. Can you hear it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear it!  The whole place hears it. The men take a few steps toward Helmut as they call for him to perform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, Doork, do a trick. How about that night in Munich when they wouldn't stop laughing.  How about it, Doork? Come on, just a little trick.  Give us one laugh.  That's all we're asking for.  Come on, Helmut, do something. Helmut, hoping to stall the inevitable, still hoping to preserve for a while longer his beautiful myth of being a great clown, holds up his hands for the men to be quiet. Franz interpreting the gesture as giving in to the demands of the men...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's going to do it!  He's going to do it! The men quiet down and move back a few steps to give Helmut room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing pleases an artist more than to perform.  I'm going to do a real show for you.  All I ask is that you give me a little time...  time to get things together...  things I can use as props...  I'll even try to make a costume, and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't need a costume.  We've got imagination. (TO MEN) Right? Murmurs of agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do the drunk pretzel like the kid suggested last night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And do it now, clown.  No more stalling. Helmut, still trying to hold on to his dream of greatness, draws himself up proudly and begins to move forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't we good enough for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd do his tricks fast enough if his guard pal asked him.  Wouldn't you, Doork? As the mention of the word "guard" the mood of the men turns ugly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV Their faces show their determination that Helmut will perform or... else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do something, Karl.  For God's sake, do something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And be sure it's funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut is frightened.  He strains to look beyond the men for help.  He opens his mouth to scream for the Guard, but Galt puts his hand over Helmut's mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You make us scream... scream with laughter...  or I'll tear you to shreds on the wire. Galt presses Helmut right up to the barbed wire fence so he can feel the barbs in his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galt takes his hand away from Helmut's mouth.  Helmut doesn't utter a sound.  He knows that Galt and the men mean business and he now must do something.  He nods his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right... all right. The men move back to give him room.  Frantically, he tries to think of something to do... he knows it must be great... or else his myth will explode.  He walks around in a little circle, trying, trying to think of something.  Finally he faces them.  He bows his legs and pretends he's a bow-legged man trying to walk a high wire, but he's so frightened the result is pathetic, not funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The camera works across their faces, which are expressionless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seeing that he is getting no reaction from his "audience", Helmut tries something else. He pulls his shirt over his head and walks around like a headless man.  He pretends to trip over some unseen object, peers through the front of his shirt at it, and stamps on the object.  Again he tries to walk over it, and again he slips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Helmut starts to repeat the same routine, many of the men are openly contemptuous.  Galt wears a smirk.  Keltner, unable to watch Helmut's degradation, moves away.  Others express their disappointment, their disdain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he's Germany's greatest clown, God help the Fatherland.  Doork, the Great!  You got paid for that?  To go without food is bad enough, but to have to watch that!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not the clown I saw.  You lied.  You're big all right.  A big liar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I was going to tell my kids!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's no clown.  Not even a bad one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am.  I am a clown! They move away from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a chance.  I just got started. But the men continue to walk away.  Helmut tries to do a hand stand, but his hands slip in the mud, and he lands ignominously on all fours.  When he looks up, only Adolf, Galt and Uhlmann remain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what we've been eating our hearts out to see! (a beat) You stink.  You really stink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I slipped.   I can do it. Seeing the disbelief on their faces, Helmut becomes almost hysterical.  He is still on his knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a clown.   I am.  I am. He pounds on the ground in frustration.  Galt spits contemptuously, and the three start to leave.  Galt turns back, looks down at Helmut.  Very deliberately, he comes forward to stand at a mud puddle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork the Great. With that he kicks a shower of mud directly into Helmut's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The mud splatters over his face.  He cries out.  His hands go to his eyes instinctively.  he kneels there, rocking back and forth in misery.  Then from o.s., we HEAR a tiny, tentative laugh -- the tiniest laugh ever heard.  Helmut looks up quickly.  He isn't sure that he heard it. Then it comes again, a little stronger.  He looks around quickly to see who has come back to taunt him, to ridicule him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV The yard is empty except for a few prisoners from other barracks way off on the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is puzzled.  Then again he hears the laugh o.s.  He turns slowly to look behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV On the other side of the fence stands a wide-eyed boy of about eight, who is watching Helmut timidly.  The ragged youngster laughs again, hesitantly, as if unsure what Helmut is doing is supposed to be funny, but finding it so nevertheless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks uncertainly at the youngster.  Is the child ridiculing him, too?  He leans over the mud puddle and looks at his reflection.  He likes what he sees.  The mud on his face looks almost like a primitive clown mask.  Very deliberately Helmut scoops up more mud and puts a blob of it on the end of his nose.  He waits for the child's reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes are laughing, but his little lips are pressed tight together.  He has been taught not to make sounds... not even sounds of laughter.  But finally what he is looking at becomes too much for him and the laughter spills out between his lips as they form a smile.  He laughs delightedly now, satisfied that Helmut is being purposely amusing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut gets to his feet, bows slightly and stiffly to the child, and then attempts another hand stand.  This time he holds himself up for a moment and then deliberately allows himself to fall on his back in the mud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he lands, he quickly glances off towards his barracks, but from the look of disappointment on his face, we know that none of his barracks mates are watching.  When he hears more laughter from o.s., he quickly rolls on his side to look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV Two more youngsters have joined the first, and all are laughing excitedly.  The first child jumps up and down, clapping his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE - FROM THE FENCE - FAVORING HELMUT Helmut gets up and bows, more deeply this time, a tribute to the children's vindication for his claim that he is a clown. He turns toward the direction of his barracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back, damn you, come back.  The children... they're laughing.  They're laughing.  I am a clown.  I am a clown. He turns back to the children and again bows.  He quickly leans down, looks at his reflection in the puddle, and scoops up a handful of mud which he plasters on his nose to make a bulbous, artificial proboscis.  He turns back to the children and in pantomime, pretends to see a fly buzzing about and tries to swat it.  The imaginary fly buzzes closer.  The CAMERA MOVES UP to -- CLOSE SHOT - HELMUT As the "fly" lands on his nose.  He looks cross-eyed at the mud blob, then swats at it.  The blob falls off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are now nine or ten youngsters at the fence, all squealing with delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bows again, and as his head comes up he looks o.s. toward his barracks, still hoping that someone will be watching his "great" success.  When he turns back to the children, we see that he continues to smile -- while tears course down his cheeks through the mud still caked on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last barracks on the open end of the camp on the political prisoners' side.  Outside the building is a low counter arrangement with two prisoners behind it serving mush and black bread to a long line of men, all of whom carry bowls and spoons. This time in mid-July, three weeks after the incident at the fence.  The day is bright and hot.  Our ANGLE FAVORS Helmut as he nears the prisoner who is serving up the mush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he moves up to be served and holds out his bowl.  The prisoner - messman spoons a blob of mush into it.  Then he looks around quickly and, before Helmut can pull back his bowl, slops another half spoonful into it with a wink at Helmut, who gives him a grateful smile in return.  Helmut moves on to the bread server, who gives him a big grin as he slips two pieces of bread into the bowl on top of the mush. Helmut hurries away, the CAMERA FOLLOWING him. He walks strangely, as if having trouble controlling his own feet.  Helmut ducks around the corner of the barracks nearest the mess hall, then peers cautiously back into the main yard. Satisfied that he hasn't been noticed, he quickly puts one piece of bread into his pocket and takes out his spoon. Holding the second piece of bread beneath the bowl, he wolfs down a few mouthfuls of the mush.  Then he smooths out the remainder with the spoon to make the mush appear untouched. He places the one slice of bread back on top of it, and studies the end result.  Nodding approval, he licks his spoon clean and puts it back in his pocket.  He goes back around the corner of the barracks into the main yard and heads for the next building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This pair of massive feet are the property of the Big Prisoner, a massive hulk of a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't know how you can go without shoes.  Soles of my feet are too sensitive. The CAMERA PANS UPWARD to the Big Prisoner and an Old Prisoner, sitting against the side of their hut.  The Old Prisoner, a frail man, with shirt off, is finishing his mush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my stomach that's sensitive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here comes your second helping. As Helmut's feet walk into FRAME and stop next to the Big Prisoner, we see the reason for his peculiar walk.  He is wearing a pair of enormous shoes, many sizes too large for him and cut open along the soles from the toes to the insteps so that they flap as he moves along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Helmut joins them and holds out his bowl of bread and mush to the Big Prisoner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. Still grinning, the Big Prisoner puts his empty bowl on the ground beside him and takes Helmut's bowl.  Holding the bread aside, he digs into the mush.  Helmut watches him eat, his own hunger written all over his face.  After a few bites, this makes the Big Prisoner a little self-concious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How're the shoes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perfect. The Big Prisoner nods and goes back to eating, satisfied that he has made a fair bargain and shouldn't be embarrassed about taking Helmut's food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't forget the bowl. The Big Prisoner, his mouth full of mush, only nods.  Helmut, tearing his eyes from the food, moves off.  The Big Prisoner watches him go.  Suddenly, he looks down at the departing Helmut's feet, and his face darkens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, Doork! Helmut stops and turns as the Big Prisoner shoves himself away from the hut and goes to him, staring down at the shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My shoes! The Big Prisoner reaches out with the large toe of one bare foot and lifts up the flapping toe of one of Helmut's shoes. He lets it drop again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said you could use 'em, not ruin 'em.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to fix them this way...  for the act, you know.  Wait till you see how funny it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  But will I feel like laughing when it gets cold!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Worry!  I'm the one who'll get frost bitten toes, not you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I return them, they'll be like new.  I promise. The Old Prisoner has finished his mush and puts his bowl down on the ground and moves forward to join Helmut and the Big Prisoner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what you've done to my shoes I should get more food.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got to have something to eat. The Big Prisoner looks at him questioningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he gives you his other meal... he'll starve to death.  Then you won't get anything. This reasoning makes sense to the Big Prisoner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember... you fix them before you bring 'em back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Promise. Helmut shakes his head "yes", turns and quickly hustles off in the direction of his own barracks, the CAMERA MOVING with him.  After a few steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV The Big Prisoner looks at Helmut, then at the piece of bread Helmut had given him.  His manner is self-conscious.  He tosses the piece of bread to Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut catches the bread, his smile expressing his thanks. The Old Prisoner puts his arm around the Big Prisoner's shoulder, while the Big Prisoner tries not to show that he is pleased with himself for his "generous" act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taking bites of the bread, Helmut, rather jauntily, lopes off toward his own barracks.  As he moves among the other prisoners, the CAMERA MOVING with him, we see many of them point or nod toward Helmut and smile good-naturedly.  Helmut is completely unaware of them, so lost is he in his own thoughts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They sit in the shade beside their barracks.  Herman is using his empty bowl as a fan.  Keltner is just finishing his food. Franz is examining his jacket, his empty bowl beside him on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean it this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't tell us.  Tell him. Franz holds up the tattered jacket to show that a button is missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What am I supposed to do? Use pins?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who has a pin? Keltner chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can laugh.  He isn't always after you for something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No? He fishes in a pocket and pulls out a large piece of chalk, holds it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Says he can mash it into a powder and put it on his face. Herman stops fanning along enough to ask...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where'd you get it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From a guard. Astonished, Herman and Franz look at him questioningly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A very bad Nazi.  Still has a heart. Herman and Franz smile.  Then Franz holds up his tattered coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish he'd have a heart and use someone else's coat. Or better yet -- his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ask him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE - FAVORING HELMUT As he comes flapping up, still munching on the piece of bread given to him by the Big Prisoner.  Keltner holds out the chalk to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally got it. Helmut takes it and examines it in a very professional manner. Herman and Franz exchange looks.  Keltner waits for Helmut to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Isn't that what you wanted?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This will do more for the act than anything.  Wait'll you see!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment there you had me worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you got smart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His conscience bothered him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought he would kill you when he saw what you had done to his shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So did I. The men laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what I'm laughing at... look at what he's doing to my coat. (holds it up) Look at it!  Yesterday a button off. And you've got it ripped here under the arm.  Besides all that falling down isn't doing it any good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got to have it.  It is the only one I can get on and still is tight enough to look funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the rate you are tearing it up, it's going to look a lot funnier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING PAST Helmut and group and in f.g. toward the main yard, where we see Galt and Uhlmann approaching.  During the ensuing dialogue, Galt spots Helmut, nudges Uhlmann and together they come toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give in, Franz.  You know he's going to talk you out of it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be careful.  I swear. Besides, I've got to have it. I explained before...  a clown can't change his costume.  It's his trademark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know... I know... but... Galt and Uhlmann join the group, looking to start trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why should he give it to a Jew clown? Right, kid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's got nothing to do with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with you bastards anyway?  All he ever did for us was cause trouble, but for them... (nodding toward the other side) ... he can't do enough. (a beat) I say he's one of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he were, he'd be over there Through this Helmut remains silent -- his eyes focused on the coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's where he belongs. Franz and Keltner get to their feet.  Herman remains seated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What're you so hot about?  It's no skin off your...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've got a good reason for not liking them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it wasn't for them... we wouldn't be in here. This surprises the men.  Herman gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A bunch of them got picked up with papers we'd sold them.   And what'd they do?  Turn us in, they did.  The ungrateful...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that was it!  Counterfeit papers. I can imagine the prices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Supply and demand, Reverend.  Supply and demand. Deliberately, Franz hands his coat to Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it, Doork -- anytime you want it. Helmut accepts the coat... nodding his head in the gracious manner of a ruler accepting homage from a faithful subject. He turns smartly and slowly struts away with as much dignity as he can muster in his big shoes which flap with every step he takes.  The others stand and stare at Galt and Uhlmann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's so terrible about what we did?  Lot of them got out of the country with our papers.  They were damn good counterfeits. Keltner, without a word, turns and goes off after Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what's more, we never charged for children.  Never.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Keltner catches up with Helmut.  The CAMERA MOVES BACK as they walk along the side of the barracks toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been meaning to ask you.  Heard anymore about the request for a review of your case? Helmut doesn't hear him as he's deep in his own thoughts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you hear the laughs I got yesterday? Keltner nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not just from the children... but the adults, too. You know where a lot of clowns make a big mistake?  They play just for the children. They forget... it's the parents, the adults that buy the tickets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never thought of that. Helmut stops, faces Keltner, a sly smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They said I couldn't come up with anything new. Keltner looks puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the circus.  Schmidt and the rest. Wait'll they see my act now.  It's funny.  Really funny. (a beat) Isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children certainly enjoy it. Helmut begins to move along again with Keltner following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What I needed was time.  Time to concentrate on new material.  A man's got to have time alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You call this being alone? Helmut takes a few more steps then stops short.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think... maybe... they'd let me go to other camps and entertain? Keltner is about to say something... but shrugs his shoulders. He knows there's not much point in trying to make Helmut look at things the way they really are.  Helmut starts to walk again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd have to get to the Commandant. Would need his permission. They arrive at the steps to the barracks.  Helmut swings Franz's coat over his shoulder as he starts up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you have time later, I'd like you to see something I've been working on.  I hunch down and do a tiny soldier parading.  Think they'll like it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?  The adults?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children, of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought the smart clown only played to the adults. Helmut, caught in a contradiction of his own "theory" of clowning, gives Keltner an annoyed look, then goes into the barracks letting the door slam behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he stands at the bottom of the steps -- he shakes his head and smiles as he marvels at the change taking place in the pompous Helmut as the little gentle clown within him struggles to emerge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA is PANNING across the faces of about forty children behind the fence as they watch Helmut o.s.  Some of them are laughing; some clapping; some squealing with glee, and a few just watching quietly, but with laughter in their eyes. Behind them, near the barracks on the non-Aryan side, a number of adults also are looking on, but they hang back, fearful that getting too close to the fence might provoke the always anticipated wrath of the guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see now that Helmut on his side of the fence is performing for the children on the other side of the menacing barbed wire fence.  Behind him, also at a safe distance because they still aren't certain of the official reaction to all of this, a number of his fellow political prisoners are watching his antics.  But, in spite of his talk about the importance of playing to the adults -- it is the children that Helmut plays to -- and it is for their laughter that he listens. The CAMERA MOVES IN to -- MED. FULL SHOT - HELMUT And we see that he has used the chalk to whiten his face. With charcoal he has blackened his eyebrows, formed a wide black mouth and drawn lines down over his eyelids to his cheekbones, giving him the appearance of a clown at once sad and happy.  At the moment he is coatless, but Franz's coast lies nearby on the ground.  For the stunt he is doing now Helmut carries the remains of an old broom and a piece of cardboard.  He is trying to sweep a small heap of dirt he has gathered onto the cardboard, but each time he tries, the dirt goes over the cardboard and he must sweep it into a pile again.  After a few attempts he feigns exasperation and ponders the problem.  Inspiration comes.  He sweeps the dirt into a pile again, bends over and very carefully sweeps it into the front of one of his shoes, holding up the split top to let it in.  This accomplished, he is very proud of himself, but when he tries to take a step, some of the dirt comes out.  Frustrated, he ponders again, and again has an inspiration.  He removes the shoe and puts it under his arm. But as he walks away with it, all the dirt slides out through the open toe.  The children roar with delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is a flaxen-haired youngster of about five who holds a weathered rag doll as she jumps up and down for sheer joy at Helmut's performance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is a completely delighted boy of perhaps seven.  Each time Helmut does something he particularly enjoys he hugs himself and spins around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl is no more than four; the boy about eight.  He clings to her hand as they watch Helmut, unsmiling, perhaps not understanding.  The boy looks at his sister, and a tiny smile tugs at her mouth.  The boy smiles back.  The girl giggles. The boy laughs outright.  They have re-discovered happiness. They look back at Helmut, both laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The older girl is ten or eleven; her sister five or six, tugs at her arm, and the older girl bends down to her.  The younger girl whispers to her, pointing to Helmut, and the older girl picks her up.  The little one puts her arms tightly around her sister's neck.  Both laugh merrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FULL SHOT - HELMUT He is putting on Franz's too-small jacket.  He tries to button it, but it won't go around him.  He sucks in his belly, but then his pants begin to slip, and he grabs at them with an embarrassed look at the laughing children. Deciding that the only way to button the coat is to hunch his shoulders, he tries that, but now his shoulders must remain hunched.  He manages to pick up the broom and puts it over his shoulder, playing soldier.  But when he tries to snap to attention, the coat pops open again, bringing another roar of laughter from Helmut's audience. Now he marches a few steps toward the CAMERA, stops, snappily puts the rifle down at rest position and salutes -- knocking himself flat.  Another roar of laughter.  As it swells, we -- PAN SHOT - JEWISH PRISONERS The laughter o.s. continues to swell as the CAMERA PANS across the faces of the adult Jewish prisoners huddled near their huts.  They smile, fearfully at first, then break into timorous laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - PAN SHOT As the laughter swells even more, the CAMERA MOVES over the faces of the political prisoners on Helmut's side of the camp.  They, too, are laughing -- some tolerantly; some at Helmut rather than with him, but they are laughing. As the laughter continues to SWELL, the CAMERA PANS over to yard-guard.  He is trying very hard not to laugh.  The result is a self-conscious giggle. As the laughter grows even louder, the CAMERA PANS as though wafted on the waves of laughter, up to a guardtower, and we see two rifle-armed soldiers in the tower watching the performance below them.  They gesture in Helmut's direction and laugh. The CAMERA continues to PAN over to the administration building and UP to an open window on the second floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SCHARFF, handsome, mid-30's, stands with his back to CAMERA at an open window in a small, but luxuriously furnished office.  The window through which he is looking opens onto the prison yard.  An AIDE pokes his head in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's coming back down the hall. Scharff nods, quickly closes the window, gives a look around the room, and follows the Aide out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Scharff comes through the door from the adjoining room. The Aide is standing in front of a small desk.  Scharff takes his position beside the door into the outer office.  They wait.  After a beat, the room's other door opens and in comes COL. HEINRICH BESTLER, a slightly built, pinch-faced SS officer in his 50's.  Scharff and Aide spring to attention and give him the salute.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler. (striding into his inner office as he passes Scharff)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bestler goes directly to the desk and sits down.  Scharff stands at attention just inside the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, stand at ease.  And, close the door. Scharff closes the door and moves over to stand near the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have to tell you why your Commandant was relieved of his command here. This prison is a disgrace. Disgrace! The latitude allowed by him will not be tolerated by me. Understand? Scharff nods his head.  Bestler gets up from the desk and walks around it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That includes the staff.  I'm going to turn this place into a model prison, a credit to the Reich. Understand? Scharff again nods his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speak up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Colonel. Bestler returns to his desk, sits, and opens a folder.  He glances up to study Scharff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't the first prison the SS has had to take over from the military. Military men are too soft to deal with those... (he nods toward the window) Scharff starts to speak but quickly changes his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were about to say something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh... I... was just going to say that I didn't hold with the soft treatment of the prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good! (taking papers from folder) Our first order of business is to prepare... He is interrupted by the SOUND of laughter o.s.  He turns slightly and looks curiously at the window, then turns back to read from the papers in the folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our first order of business is to prepare all non-Aryan prisoners for shipment in two weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are they being sent, Colonel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Work camps. Again the SOUND of laughter from o.s. and Bestler looks quickly at the window, irritated.  Scharff, uncertain of his superior's reaction, tries to cover up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we have about 40 children, some only babies, with more scheduled to arrive tomorrow or the next day. They're not going to be much use in a work camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm aware of that.  This order covers only the adult prisoners over fifteen. We won't have to wet nurse the children for long.  Other plans are being made for... Again he is interrupted by the laughter o.s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that? Before Scharff can answer, Bestler goes to the window and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bestler through the window, we can see Helmut performing for the children.  Bestler watches for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that supposed to be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - MED. SHOT Scharff goes to the window and looks over Bestler's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That!  Well, you see, sir, one of the prisoners used to be a circus clown.  Sometimes he gives a little... well...  a sort of show -- for the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A show!  Is this a prison camp or a traveling circus! (he looks out window again) Am I correct in assuming that those children are on the non-Aryan side of the camp?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the... buffoon?  A German?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Colonel. Bestler sits on the side of the desk and looks at Scharff, who tries very hard not to show how uncomfortable he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I to believe you aren't aware of the general order absolutely forbidding fraternization?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know about it, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close the window. Scharff carefully closes the window.  Bestler walks around desk to stand leaning against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just what do you think fraternization means, Lieutenant Scharff ?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Communication.   Social contact. Giving aid, talking... (shrugs helplessly)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long has this been going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just the last two or three weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the Commandant approved?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, sir, children are very hard to handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This clown!  Who is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's... I know.  It's Doork, the Great.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not his clown name, you idiot.  His number.  His identification.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I have the Colonel's permission to leave, I will check it at once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Later.  Right now I want these performances halted.  Understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Bestler begins shuffling papers from the folder.  Scharff, uncertain whether he has been dismissed or not, hesitates. Bestler glances up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Immediately!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir ! He salutes and bolts from the room, almost crashing into the door in his flight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FULL SHOT - DAY Shooting past the children in f.g. to Helmut through the fence, as he bows to the applauding youngsters.  Behind him we can see a number of soldier-guards coming through the cordon of watching prisoners, and waving them to disperse. They do so reluctantly, as the guard from Helmut's barrack moves forward to Helmut, who is just about to start another routine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all.  Show's over.  Everybody clear out. Helmut stops, startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to include children across the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back to the barrack. (to children) You heard me.  Show's over. The children don't move, but stand staring at Helmut as if waiting for him to tell them what to do.  This frustrates the guard, who isn't accustomed to being questioned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on.  Get away. Still the children refuse to budge.  Angry, the guard goes close to the fence, waving his arms at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Move, damn it, before I come over there and... The youngsters scuttle back a few feet fearfully, but there they stop, their eyes still on Helmut.  The guard turns to Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get them moving before somebody gets hurt. Helmut goes up to the fence and speaks to the children softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's all the show for today.  Go back inside. The children back away with long faces.  Finally convinced that Helmut is through, they turn and wander back toward their barracks, but with many a backward look at him.  Helmut continues to encourage them, as the guard looks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right now, go along.  I'll see you tomorrow.  Goodbye.  Goodbye. Until tomorrow. Many of the children wave to him.  The guard takes Helmut by the arm, turns him toward the barrack and hustles him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TWO SHOT - HELMUT, GUARD The CAMERA MOVES BACK as they come toward it, the guard firmly propelling Helmut along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get inside and take that stuff off your face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.  What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Orders.  No more shows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean... not ever?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we weren't doing any harm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commandant thinks you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commandant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new Commandant.  He minds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just because I make them laugh a little...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know the rule... no mixing with Jews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't mixing!  I was only... The guard stops him and turns him so that they are face to face.  The CAMERA MOVES UP TO -- TIGHT TWO SHOT - HELMUT, GUARD GUARD (quietly, threatening) Look, it's not my order.  It's the Commandant's. (more kindly) Now do what I tell you and save yourself a lot of grief. He pushes Helmut toward his barrack and then turns and walks off, the CAMERA PULLING BACK to -- WIDER ANGLE Helmut watches the guard go, then, dejectedly, shuffles toward his barrack.  As he nears it, Keltner, Franz, Adolf, Herman, Ludwig, and the other regulars intercept him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They crowd around Helmut, anxious to know what's happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says I've got to stop -- with the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been expecting it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because they're Jews?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of the laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why should that bother them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you rule by fear, laughter is the most frightening sound in the world. Silently the men walk up the steps and into the barrack, the CAMERA PANNING with them until we...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a warm, sunny afternoon and most of the prisoners on both sides of the fence, are out warming their weary bones. On the Aryan side, a number of prisoners, including Ludwig and Herman, are having a makeshift soccer game using a bound bundle of rags for a ball.  They play with fierce rigor for such emaciated men, yelling at each other and kicking up clouds of dust as they try to work off their frustrations. On the non-Aryan side of the fence, the children, now about 50 in number, are grouped near the wire barricades staring across it, their faces dour.  It appears they are watching the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT - CHILDREN Shooting past the soccer players in f.g. toward the fence. Through the men we can see the children, but the play moves away from them.  They continue to stare straight ahead, obviously watching something else.  Suddenly many of them press close to the fence straining to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut can be seen standing in the doorway.  After a beat, he quickly retreats back into the barrack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The CAMERA MOVES BACKWARD down the aisle between the bunks as Helmut walks dejectedly down the aisle, nervously fingering his white ascot.  The barrack is empty except for Keltner, who is arranging the sprouts of his potato plant over a little trellis of sticks.  Helmut turns and walks back up the aisle to stand in front of Keltner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't go out there.  I can't take another day of them staring at me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll get over it.  Disappointment is no stranger to those children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at me as though it was all my fault.  Haven't they been told why I can't...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure they have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why do they stare?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's amazing how a thing like this can feed off itself.  Think how lucky we would be if we could do that. Helmut glances disinterestedly at the plant as he reaches up to his bunk and brings down the coat belonging to Franz.  He holds coat up for Keltner to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sewed a button on.  Look all right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Helmut gently pats the coat, then folds it and puts it back on his bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did make them laugh.  Didn't I? Keltner nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish they'd get them out of here. Prison is no place for little children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been all over that before. You've got to stop thinking about them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right!  I've got to think of myself. Keltner puts the plant under his bunk and gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too hot in here.  I'm going to get some air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Johann... do you think there's any possible way I could talk to the Commandant.  Maybe I could make him understand... The sentence trails off as Helmut realizes how useless his suggestion is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing you can do... but forget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can I!  They were my own very special audience.  And now they stare at me as if I had betrayed them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're children, Helmut.  You can't expect them to understand the madness of adults.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I could talk to them.  To the children themselves -- that would help, wouldn't it? Keltner doesn't answer but he watches Helmut with new interest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I explain it to them -- then they'll know I am not mad at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You go near that fence once again... and you're taking your life in your own hands.  You know that as well as I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would just need a minute.  A minute to talk to them. Helmut goes to the door and looks out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV The children are still pressed against the fence, still trying to get a glimpse of Helmut
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut stands just inside the doorway... looking out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish to God I didn't care.  I wish to God I could forget them. Helmut walks back to Keltner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I can't. Helmut looks at Keltner, his eyes pleading for help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to ask you a question, Helmut, and I want you to think carefully before you answer. Helmut nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The reason you can't get them out of your mind -- is it because you need them -- for you audience? Helmut drops his eyes as he attempts to find the right answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know I can't perform for them anymore.  I know that. (a beat) I really don't know what the reason is.  I think it's got something to do with... well, I don't want those little ones to think I've turned against them, too.  That's why I've got to do something.  Something. Keltner studies Helmut for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll be taking a chance.  A great chance. Helmut nods that he know this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right!  Come on then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to talk to the children? Well, I think I can help you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no reason for you to get involved in this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reason?  When war is waged against children!  That is reason enough for the whole damn world to get involved. And it will, believe me, it will. Keltner puts his arm around Helmut's shoulder.  Helmut grins, a broad grin of thanks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, come on, Doork the Great, let's start getting involved. They both walk quickly to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Keltner and Helmut come out.  In the b.g. we can see the soccer game still going on, the players shouting excitedly at each other.  Keltner surveys the scene for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait here. He moves down the line of barracks toward the mess hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Keltner moves among the men lounging around the barracks, talking and watching the soccer game.  Trying to appear as nonchalant as possible, we whispers something to a group of prisoners.  They glance back at Helmut and then nod.  Keltner moves on to another group, taking care to avoid the two yard guards, one of which is the guard in charge of Barrack "H". Again Keltner murmurs something to the other prisoners, and again they look at Helmut and nod assent.  Keltner goes on to another group.  As he does, the men in the first group casually disperse and start across the yard toward the fence, moving around the soccer players.  One of them goes up to Ludwig, who is playing in the match, and whispers something to him.  Ludwig nods, and the other prisoners move away. Ludwig runs off chasing the "ball".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he storms into a clutch of players, including Galt, all kicking at the "ball".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kessler is going to talk to the children. Cover him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who says so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Reverend says cover him... so we cover him. The players around Galt give him a meaningful look and he gets their message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right!  I was just asking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Keltner's plot takes shape, we see a dozen or so prisoners wander, apparently aimlessly, across the yard and form a spectator's section for the soccer game with their backs to the fence, thus providing a shield between the children and the guards.  The game picks up tempo, but the play somehow stays in the center of the yard, strengthening the shield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he watches the plan in action.  Keltner rejoins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what to do? Helmut nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay behind the men and keep an eye out for the guards on the other side.
direction.name: direction
