direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make it quick.  You won't have much time. Helmut nods again and starts away, but Keltner stops him
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Helmut, keep the children quiet. We don't want trouble. Helmut nods and moves off across the yard.  The CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he circles around the soccer players, trying to look as if he is just wandering over to join the other spectators. As he nears the other side, the children spot him and react, pressing closer to the fence and pointing to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT - HELMUT Shooting past the children in f.g. toward Helmut as he nears the line of prisoners, who continue to ad lib shouts of derision and encouragement to the soccer players.  The children begin ad libbing cries of greeting to Helmut.  He puts his fingers to his lips to silence them and takes his place in the line with his back to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he stands pretending to watch the soccer game with the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kick it, Ludwig.  Kick it! The prisoner next to him gives him a sidelong glance and nods almost imperceptibly.  Quickly, Helmut ducks behind the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the line as he scurries, bending over, to the fence. The children flock to him.  The CAMERA FOLLOWS him to the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork, Doork, Doork is back.  It's Doork.  It's Doork. Helmut tries to silence their squeals of delight.  Holding a finger to his lips:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shhh.  Shhhh.  The guards... The children quiet down and press closer to the fence.  Helmut drops to his knees, looking around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do a trick, Doork.  Please, Doork, please, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no.  I can't.  The guards won't let me.  Not now.  Maybe some other day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the same flaxen-haired little five-year-old with a doll we saw before.  She regards Helmut solemnly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're bad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Smiling wryly at the simplicity of this appraisal, Helmut reaches through the fence and pats the head of the girl's doll. Eager to touch Helmut, another child take his hand, others grab at his arm.  Still other youngsters, following this lead, try to reach through the fence to touch him.  Obviously enjoying this adulation, Helmut takes as many of the little hands as he can, squeezing them affectionately.  Only one group of eight children hangs back.  They do not seem to understand what this is all about.  Their little faces are fearful, yet they are fascinated by Helmut.  Suddenly one little boy gives a yelp of pain and backs away from the wire, clutching his forearm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?  What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurt himself. Wide-eyed with fright, the little boy takes his hand away from his arm to reveal a nasty looking scratch from one of the barbs on the fence.  Seeing his own injury, the youngster bursts into tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shhh.  Shhh.  Don't cry.  It's going to be all right. (to the other children) Be careful when you're near this fence. He consoles the little boy, who continues to cry and holds up his wounded arm for Helmut to see.  Helmut looks around frantically, as if hoping to find help somewhere.  Then he quickly removes his ascot -- his precious trademark, the symbol of his self-accorded status -- and hands it through the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, wrap this around it.  I'll make it all better. The little boy goes on crying, but some of the other children take the cravat and fashion it into a crude bandage around the youngster's arm.  It fails to silence the boy's crying, however.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hush now.  Stop crying.  Please. Look... Look at this. He begins shuffling around on his knees, imitating a duck in an effort to appease the crying child.  As he goes, Helmut quacks softly.  The boy stops crying, but his face remains unhappy.  The other children laugh in spite of Helmut's efforts to keep them quiet, all but the group of eight youngsters who only stare at Helmut in awe.  Seeing that he is making progress with the crying child, Helmut next pulls his coat up over his head and, still on his knees, moves around like a headless man, groping ahead with his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His frown gradually dissolves and, in spite of his sniffling, he smiles, timorously at first, then broadly.  Finally, he laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut shrugs his jacket back into place and smiles at the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There, that's better.  No more crying now. For the first time he notices the other group of frowning children.  Among the other smiling and laughing youngsters, they seem to stand out.  When Helmut fastens a quizzical look on them, they back away a little, fearfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter with them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're new.  We can't understand them.  All they do is cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're all the way from Czechoslovakia. The eight just start at him wordlessly, their fear naked in their eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's nothing to be afraid of. Everything is all right. When there is no reaction from the children, who obviously don't understand him, Helmut looks over his shoulder, wondering if he has time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT - PRISONERS - HELMUT'S POV The prisoners are still rooting for the soccer players, but as Helmut looks, Adolf, in the middle of the cheering section, turns and sees him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurry up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut nods to Adolf and then turns back to the youngsters, afraid but still unable to tear himself away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here.  Look.  I'll show you... No noise now. In pantomime, he pretends to pull a hair from his head and threads it through an imaginary needle.  Finally accomplishing this, he pretends to be sewing a button on his jacket, holding the thumb of his left hand under the button while he sews with his right.  When he has finished, he pantomimes that he has sews his thumb to the jacket.  He pretends to be embarrassed and tries to hide his hand in his trouser pocket, but in order to put his hand in his pocket the jacket goes too.  The children giggle, then roar with laughter at his frantic efforts to detach his thumb from his jacket. The silent children press closer to watch Helmut's antics. Some look at each other and smile, then grin.  Suddenly the entire group is laughing.  Helmut holds up his hands for silence, but the grin on his face says he loves it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, be quiet.  Be quiet.  Shhh. Shhhh. The children go on laughing as if this is just part of the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT - TOWER GUARDS The SOUND of the children's laughter floats up to two guards in a tower on the non-Aryan side of camp.  One of them, who has been watching the soccer game below, nudges his partner and points down to Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - GUARDS' POV Between the children at the fence and the line of soccer spectators we can see only the top of Helmut's head bobbing up and down.  But that is enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LONG SHOT - TOWER GUARDS After a long look, one of the guards picks up a telephone and starts to make a call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut seems to have thrown caution away under the stimulus of the children's laughter.  He is on his feet trying a hand spring.  He lands flat on his back, but rolls over on his side and grins broadly at his audience, which laughs appreciatively.  This is the old Doork.  Their Doork.  Again Helmut tries the hand spring and again he flops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with Helmut and the children in f.g. and beyond them the Aryan side of the yard.  The soccer game is still in progress, with the spectators on both sides of the action whooping it up.  Then in b.g. we see two soldiers, two SS officers, and the guard in charge of barracks "H", come bursting through the spectators near the huts and into the game itself.  The players slowly subside as they realize what is happening.  They watch the guard cross the yard. The cheering trails off, and the yard becomes strangely quiet, the prisoners' warning to Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oblivious to all this in his joy at performing for the children again, Helmut is just pretending to slip on something underfoot.  His arms flay the air as he tries to regain his balance, but he falls.  Through this, however, the children seem to be watching something behind Helmut, and when he lands on the ground, they do not laugh. Again their faces are frightened as they look o.s.  Helmut looks at them, puzzled.  Then, realizing that something is wrong, he turns and looks up from the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOOTING PAST Helmut in f.g. toward the guard, SS men, and soldiers, who have come through the line of spectators and stand glowering at him.  The prisoners have moved back, warily watching for the next move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wouldn't listen, would you? Almost wearily, he goes to the fence.  This isn't something he likes, but his authority is at stake here, and he has no choice.  As the CAMERA PANS him to the fence we see that some non-Aryan adults have drifted over to see what the disturbance is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on.  Get back. The children don't move.  Their eyes are on Helmut.  The guard shouts over to the adults standing behind the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You back there, get them out of here. The adults begin to gather up the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They had nothing to do with it.  It was all my doing. The guard turns and comes up to face Helmut.  He studies him for a moment, then hits him a vicious backhand slap across the face.  Taken by surprise, Helmut staggers backward and falls.  A murmur runs through the prisoners.  The children still near the fence, cry out with alarm.  Seeing their terror, Helmut is determined to make it look like just another act.  With a painful effort he gets to his feet, smiles at the children, turns and salutes the guard, knocking himself down again.  A couple of children giggle.  The FIRST SS OFFICER quickly steps forward to stand behind the guard. He holds a swagger stick in his right hand, which he repeatedly whacks into the palm of his left hand.  He looks down at Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get up. Helmut struggles to his feet.  He glances over at the children.  They are all watching him.  He takes a deep breath, winks at the little ones, then salaams before the SS Officer and the guard.  Some of the children giggle.  This infuriates the SS officer.  He raises the swagger stick and brings it down hard on Helmut's head knocking him to his knees.  The children scream with terror.  The SS Officer raises the stick to hit Helmut again, but Keltner, in an almost instinctive reaction, catches hold of his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children! Not in front of the children!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - KELTNER The SS Officer turns and brings the stick down on Keltner. He hits him over and over, each blow more vicious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FRIGHTENED CHILDREN IN B.G. Helmut turns away from the beating, pulls his jacket up over his head and starts to walk around like a headless man stumbling and falling over his own feet.  The children, many still screaming, turn their eyes away from the SS Officer to watch Helmut's antics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The horror-stricken men stand frozen as the SS Officer continues to hit Keltner until he drops to the ground. Suddenly Franz breaks away from the men and charges at the First SS Officer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - FRANZ Franz runs INTO CAMERA and attempts to stop the First SS Officer.  The Second SS Officer whips his pistol out, aims carefully and FIRES a shot into Franz's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uhlmann stands speechless and dumbfounded.  Galt cowers. Beads of perspiration pour from his brow.  Adolf weeps bitter tears as Herman places his arm around his shoulder to comfort him, and himself as well.  Ludwig, dead to any emotion, simply turns and walks away into the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut is now, more than ever, the clown, as he goes into a frenzied version of the "Clap Dance".  The complete incongruity of his behavior leaves the spectators stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE - SHOWING THE CHILDREN IN B.G. The children are no longer screaming, instead they are watching Helmut as though they are hypnotized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guard, fully aware that the sadist SS men may take action against Helmut, quickly motions for two of the other guards to take Helmut away.  The First SS Officer, still panting with exhaustion, shows his approval of the action taken by the guard.  The two guards seize Helmut by the arms and begin dragging him off toward the administration building.  The prisoners move away before the guards holding Helmut, forming a sort of line of march for them.  As they drag Helmut along, he waves back at the children, makes a funny face and moves his feet in something approaching a dance step.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the cell toward the door.  The cell is about eight feet long and four feet wide with a steel door at the far end.  The cell is bare.  We HEAR men approaching, and a guard opens the door letting in a shaft of bright light.  Two guards hoist the unconcious Helmut into the cell and drop him onto the floor.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: INT.
location: NO LIGHT SHOOTING FROM THE BACK

direction.raw_text: He lies in a heap on the floor, his face swollen from a severe beating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guards walk out, slamming the door shut leaving the cell pitch dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Window shade quickly rolls up letting in a steam of blinding sunlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lt. Scharff is by the window, having just rolled up the window shade.  Colonel Bestler is on the phone and obviously exasperated by what he is hearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (on phone) Yes. (pause) Yes.  Yes, I understand perfectly. However, I don't see how we can be held responsible. (pause) Our orders were very clear.  We were to have the freight car ready to be picked up at midnight. (pause) Of course, I'm aware the operation must be kept secret. (pause) I just don't have the staff to send down there now and... Yes, I'll wait. He puts hand over mouthpiece to talk to Scharff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The freight car wasn't picked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's still down there on the siding!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some stupid mix up.  If they think... The SOUND of the voice coming over the phone causes him to literally snap to attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, General. (pause) Yes, I'm as distressed about the situation as you are. (long pause during which he nods his head) Yes.  Personally!  Immediately! Yes, General.  You can leave it in my hands. (pause) Heil Hitler! He puts down the instrument and turns at once to Scharff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who did you leave in charge down there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant Hoffman.  Very reliable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apparently not reliable enough.  The cargo seems to be raising quite a fuss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifty children, sir!  In a boxcar!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  I know.  But the siding isn't far from town.  The General doesn't want unauthorized persons getting curious.  Understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get some men down there right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Men!  You'll get yourself down there. And take at least a dozen guards with you.  Don't let anyone get close to that boxcar...  under any circumstances.  No one !
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Scharff turns to leave the office, but after a few steps he stops and turns back toward Bestler, a look of concern on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir? Bestler looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wondered, sir, if you might have any suggestions as... well...  how do we quiet children?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Use any method you can, but shut them up.  That's an order. Scharff is disappointed at not getting some help from Bestler. Suddenly his face brightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, the clown! Bestler looks at him quizzically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The one who amused the children
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out of the question.  The man's being disciplined for that very thing.  We can't change our position now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one need know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'd know. Scharff thinks this over.  Suddenly his face brightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, if I could guarantee he'd never say anything. Bestler looks interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, sir, he's been trying to get a review of his case.  Claims he's here by mistake.  I could tell him you would recommend the review.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man who wants something.  Good. Very good strategy, Lieutenant. (he turns to face Scharff) However, when you bring him back here, return him to solitary and keep him there. (a beat) I've seen the best of men, after several years in solitary, unable to remember even their own names.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I have your permission to take the clown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Permission granted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small open truck with 12 soldiers in the back, followed by a staff car, move along the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is in the front seat, Helmut and Scharff in the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SCHARFF Helmut has been cleaned up, but still shows the effects of the beating and his stay in solitary.  Holding a small mirror, he is applying his makeup.  He occasionally closes or tries to shade his eyes from the light.  They ride on in silence. Scharff stares straight ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wish you could've gotten the big shoes.  The children laugh so when they see them flopping up and down. Scharff makes no reply.  Helmut starts to put on his big black mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commandant, himself, asked for me! (a beat) You say he's personally requesting a review of my case!  Why, that means I'm practically on my way back to Berlin. (studies mouth in mirror) Should be red.  Mouth looks better in red. (a beat) Know the first thing I'm going to do when I get to Berlin?  Buy an overcoat with a fur collar.  Had such a coat. Very elegant. Very elegant. (finishing the up- turned corners of mouth) It's a good idea... moving the children. Scharff reacts to this.  He looks sharply at Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Prison's no place for children. I said all along that it was some kind of mistake.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finish your makeup.  We're almost there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know what Johann Keltner said?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keltner.  From my barracks.  The minister. He said... Let me think. He said... men who wage war on children. That's it. Men who wage war on children... commit such a crime... (a beat as he thinks) ... such a heinous crime.  That's it.  Men who wage war on children commit such a heinous crime that even the devil damns their souls. Scharff looks as though he'd just been slapped across the face.  He quickly turns toward the window.  Helmut inspects his reflection in the mirror as he draws black vertical lines down over each eye -- giving him a very lost, sad, dejected look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LONG SHOT - DAY as the truck and staff car leave the highway and jolt down a short roadway to a railroad siding where a boxcar sits on the tracks.  Uniformed GUARDS stand watch on both sides of the car, which has the door nearest the CAMERA, partially open.  The truck and staff car pull up to the nearest boxcar. The soldiers jump from the rear of the truck, one of them carrying a large burlap sack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Scharff gets out of the car, from the boxcar comes the SOUND of children crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait here. Scharff strides purposefully over to Sergeant Hoffman, the guard beside the open door.  Hoffman salutes Scharff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any word about the train yet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir.  The last we heard -- it won't get here until evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anyone been around?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all that wailing, it's a wonder. Couldn't you keep them quiet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't know what to do, Lieutenant. I was afraid to close both doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep a tight guard on the whole area. No one gets near here.  Understand? (to Hoffman) You post them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Hoffman moves over to soldiers and begins giving them their orders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave that here. The soldier puts down the sack, and hurries off after the others with Hoffman leading the way.  Scharff turns toward the staff car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Over here, Clown. Helmut quickly gets out of the car and moves over to Scharff. He looks toward the partially open door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take that in to them. Helmut picks up the sack and peers into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bread.  They won't wait so loud with their mouths full.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How... how long have they been here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just get in there and keep them quiet.  You can do that, can't you? Helmut nods.  Scharff puts his hand on Helmut's shoulder. Helmut stiffens under his touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do a good job and I'll personally ask that you get a favorable decision on your case.  Understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Helmut moves over to the half open door of the boxcar, the CAMERA MOVING with him.  Just before he looks inside, he puts a wide grin on his face.  But when he does peer into the car, his eyes cease to smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In one end of the car the children are huddled together in one frightened, wailing mass.  They do not even notice Helmut at first, so great is their sorrow.  The little ones cling to the larger youngsters, who, in turn, cling together.  The small ones weep hysterically , as children do when they have been crying for a very long time.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK so that Helmut is in f.g.   He slides the boxcar door open fully, throwing more light on the children.  This brings renewed walls of anguish from the youngsters, who cluster together more fiercely.  But one little boy sneaks a look at the door, expecting to see more guards.  When he sees Helmut, his tear- filled eyes widen.  He can scarcely believe what he sees, much less verbalize it.  He tugs frantically at an OLDER GIRL he has been clutching.  She looks first at him, then at Helmut.  She, too, can hardly believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork? (shrill with recognition) It's Doork.  It is!  It is! The children begin untangling quickly.  Faces appear between legs, around skirts and over shoulders.  For a moment they can only stare at Helmut, speechless with wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So this is where you've been hiding? That breaks the silence, and the children begin squealing ad- libbed expressions of greeting and relief.  They repeat his name time and again:  "Doork, Doork, Doork."  As one... the youngsters surge toward him.  The little boy who first saw him reaches him first.  He drops to his knees and puts his arms around Helmut's neck, hugging him furiously.  Helmut returns the embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to go home.  Take me home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, now, there's nothing to cry about.  We're going to have fun. (disengaging himself and picking up the sack) Here.  I brought you something. (he tosses it into the car) The children pounce on the sack and tug at it, unsure what it is except that it's a gift from Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait now.  Don't open it yet.  Wait'll I get in.  You help me. He backs up a few steps, the CAMERA PULLING BACK with him. Then he runs toward the car and, with strength he really doesn't have, jumps up so that he gets his arms on the floor of the boxcar.  He heaves himself forward partially into it, and the children grab his clothes to help him inside.  A couple of the older boys seize the seat of his pants and finally pull him in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut as he rolls over and jumps up, waggling his head from side to side in the manner of a Jack-in-the-box. The children watch him big-eyed.  A few giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm a Jack-in-the-box. He gestures around to indicate that he is, indeed, in a box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all Jacks-in-the-box -- the same box. The children laugh, and some begin imitating Helmut's head movements.  Others do the same, and still others, including the Czech youngsters, until all are waggling their heads at each other and loving it.  Then, out of sheer adoration, the youngest of the children close in on Helmut and hug him around his legs.  Slowly he stops waggling his head and stretches out his arms to embrace as many of them as he can -- almost as if trying to protect them.  Suddenly the gaiety dissolves, and the children go solemnly silent.  Helmut reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... who's hungry. Almost in unison, the children shout "I am", again forgetting their unhappiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, I want everybody to sit down.  When I count three, everybody sit.  Ready?   One, two... On the count of two, many of the youngsters sit down.  Helmut feigns surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you're too fast.  Three! This brings a burst of giggles, and the remaining children, sit down... the Czechs following the example of the others. Helmut opens the burlap sack and begins handing out pieces of black bread.  The children grab at the chunks and gnaw it voraciously.  When all of the youngsters have been given the bread, Helmut takes a piece and bites into it with great relish.  After a few chews on the bread:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now... what'll we do? There is a long moment of silence, then the little blonde girl with the rag doll speaks up timidly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to see my Mommy. Helmut is brought up short.  For a beat he searches his brain frantically for an answer.  Then he goes to the child and kneels beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You would?  All right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know where she is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's right here with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't see her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's because you don't know how to look.  I'll show you.  Close your eyes. (to the other children) All of you... close your eyes. The little girl closes her eyes and one by one the other youngsters do also.  The Czech children look at each other, then at the other children, then they too close their eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody's eyes shut?  Now, think about your mommys and Daddys... There, don't you see them?  Can't you see their faces? The children, marvelling at this feat, ad lib expressions of assent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you see!  They're right here with you.  All you have to do is look in your hearts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does Mommy see me, Doork?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, she does.  She has you safe in her heart, too. The silence in the car tells Helmut that sadness has returned to the children.  He brightens quickly and rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got an idea.  You all know my name, but I don't know yours.  So let's find out everybody's name, shall we? He points to a boy of about ten in the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You... come here and I'll show you what we'll do. The boy, honored at being singled out, rises and comes to Helmut, who takes a stubby pencil from his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Willie.  That's a good name.  How do you spell it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.  I'll just write that on top of your head. Using the eraser end of the pencil, Helmut carefully traces the letters on top of the boy's head.  The youngster peers upward, wondering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There.  See, this way we'll all be able to tell everybody else's name just by looking at his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: still looking up, but now doubtful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course I did.  Here... He pulls an older boy to his feet, winks at him and points to the first boy's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him what it says.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It says Willie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?  Truly? He puts his hand to his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful.  Don't smear it. (he glances around) Let's see now... Yes.  You shall be next. He points to a Czech girl of about six.  He motions for her to come over to him.  She shyly bows her head.  Her friends push her forward. Helmut holds out his hand to her, she grabs it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is your name? She looks at him, then at the other Czech children.  They all giggle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me.  I don't speak your language. He gently plants a kiss on her cheek and she puts an arm around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See!  We understand each other. Now... (he points to Willie) Willie. (he points to himself) Doork. (points again to Willie) Willie. (pointing to himself) Doork. The child's eyes light up and she whispers into Helmut's ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beautiful name!  Now you tell all the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inga.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's such a pretty name... say it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inga! She quickly bows her head for Helmut to outline her name on the top of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .  There it is. The little girl gives a quick curtsy and hurries back to her group.  Helmut glances around at the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's see now.  Who wants to be next. The little girl with the doll presses forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You? Shaking her head she holds up the doll.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So the little children will know her name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.  That way she can't get lost, can she?  What's her name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frederika.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frederika? He studies the top of doll's tiny head.  Then he holds up his hand and measures off a distance of about three inches in the air with thumb and forefinger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Frederika! Next he puts the doll's head between his thumb and forefinger, illustrating that the head is too small for the name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Couldn't we just make it Freda?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no!  Frederika. Helmut shrugs, closes one eye and begins writing in tiny letters on the doll's head.  The children laugh delightedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sergeant Hoffmann is walking his post beside the open door of the boxcar.  Inside we can see Helmut and the children and HEAR their laughter. The CAMERA PANS over to the staff car, where Scharff sits in the front seat smoking a cigarette and waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is perhaps two hours later.   Sergeant Hoffman is now leaning wearily against the boxcar near the door.  The CAMERA PANS over to the staff car, where Scharff is dozing in the back seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From within the boxcar we can HEAR Helmut SINGING softly to the children.  Sergeant Hoffman is listening.  Finally he takes something from his pocket, goes to the door of the boxcar and sticks his head inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children are scattered about, either sleeping or near sleep, many of them cuddled close to Helmut, who sits near the door with his back against the side of the car, crooning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clown.  Clown, can you play one of these? He holds out a harmonica.  Helmut leans over to get it, being careful not to disturb the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got it to send home to my boy... but if it'll help...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will.  It will. (he takes it)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't say anything to the Lieutenant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I promise. He leans back and looks at the harmonica, then he has a sudden thought as Hoffman's head disappears.  He leans back toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guard... guard. Hoffman reappears at door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's going to be dark soon.  The little ones may be afraid.  Do you think... well... could you get some kind of a light for in here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to get me in trouble? Helmut nods that he understands Hoffman's situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would if I could.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know.  I know you would. Again Hoffman's face disappears.  Helmut leans back and begins experimenting with the harmonica.  Actually he can play it only slightly, but he manages to get some sort of soft tune out of it.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY to include the children, most of who are resting peacefully, secure in Helmut's presence.  But suddenly a little dark haired, dark- eyed girl of about six, sits upright and cries out, frightened by a bad dream.  Helmut reacts.  The child looks around the boxcar as if she can't remember how she got there and begins crying inconsolably.  Some of the other children stir.  Helmut quickly but carefully disengages himself from the tots around him and picks his way over to the girl.  He kneels beside her, and the CAMERA MOVES UP to -- TIGHT TWO SHOT - HELMUT, DARK-EYED GIRL The child continues crying, but more softly, he wide wet eyes on Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter? (she only stares at him) It's all right -- just a bad dream. He tries to put a comforting arm around her, but she shrinks away continuing to sob softly.  Realizing that words won't help, he turns to the harmonica for communication, serenading her with a soft but sprightly tune of his own improvisation. It is hardly a masterpiece, but it has the desired effect. The girl stops sobbing, and when Helmut finishes the tune he makes a real funny face and she timorously puts a hand up to touch his make-up, but pulls it back quickly.  With an affectionate smile, Helmut takes her hand and runs it over his face, pretending that her touch tickles him.  As he laughs, the child begins to smile faintly.  He shows her the traces of chalk make-up on her fingers, and she giggles. His conquest is all but complete.  He picks the youngster up, and holding her like a dancing partner, pretends to dance with her to a little tune he hums.  She loves this and laughs outright.  When Helmut finally puts her down, he kisses her on the cheek and turns his cheek in an unspoken request for a return kiss.  The girl shyly and quickly gives Helmut's cheek a peck.  Grinning, Helmut pats the spot where she kissed him to show his appreciation for her wonderful gift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE The older girl we saw earlier calls to him in a hushed voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork. Helmut moves over and squats down beside her and the CAMERA MOVES IN to -- CLOSE TWO SHOT - HELMUT, OLDER GIRL OLDER GIRL Where are they sending us?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have children? Helmut looks around at the children.  He smiles sadly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scharff, dozing in the back seat, is awakened by the SOUND of an approaching train o.s.  He listens, glances at his watch, shakes his head and gets out of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Scharff strides to the boxcar, where Sergeant Hoffman has also hear the locomotive.  He salutes as Scharff comes up, the CAMERA FOLLOWING him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It finally got here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Help them get the car coupled on. We want to move it out of here as fast as possible.  Be sure the doors are locked.  And, get the clown off. Hoffman salutes, and Scharff moves off toward the approaching locomotive and freight cars being backed up to the boxcar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - (STOCK) It is backing down the siding toward the boxcar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With a cautious look around, he reaches under the waiting boxcar and brings out a box-type, battery operated lantern. He goes to the boxcar door and peers inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, clown, time to get off. Helmut appears at the door and looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Train is here.  They are hooking it up now. (he hoists the lantern inside) Here.  Tell them not to light it up until the doors are closed. Helmut gives him a look of deep gratitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And get off right now. Just then the boxcar is jolted as the locomotive makes contact and Hoffman runs off toward the front of the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The jolt has awakened several of the children, who gather around Helmut in the dimness of the car, frightened and bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're moving.  What's happening? What was the noise?  Doork, where are we going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's nothing.  You're going for a train ride.  What do you think of that?  A real train ride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it far?  Are you coming, too?  I don't want a train ride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it'll be fun.  I would like to come, but I don't think I can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please come, Doork.  Please.  Please. Please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't.  They want me to stay here. There are cries from the children, whose pleading eyes make Helmut terribly uncomfortable.  He backs toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But... I'll come to see you.  Soon as I can. And, I want you all to promise me to be very good.  No crying. The children stare at him silently, their eyes unconsciously accusing.  With him goes all their security.  Helmut knows it, but he has no choice.  When he reaches the door...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you want me...  remember, just close your eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wordlessly, she shuts her eyes -- tight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Following the dark-eyed girl's example, the smaller children one by one, close their eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Near tears with emotion, he wavers.  Then with great control..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and sits down on the floor of the car with his feet hanging outside.  He is just about to jump down when he is stopped by a LOUD WAIL of anguish from one of the children behind him.  He turns and looks back at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV A BOY of about six, one of the Czech youngsters, is crying with the dejection of a lad who has just lost everything. The other little Czechs and the older girl who first recognized Helmut at the boxcar door are trying unsuccessfully to console him.  Between cooing and patting the boy's shoulder, the girl throws accusing looks at Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE - TO INCLUDE HELMUT Uncertain what to do, Helmut glances around outside. Satisfied that the train isn't going to move at once, he gets up and goes to the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this now?  Crying?  After all the fun we've had? The boy only looks at Helmut and goes right on crying.  Helmut looks helplessly at the older girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's his birthday.  He thought there would be presents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a Czech.   Do you speak...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not! Helmut is angry with the girl because he really wants to get off the train and yet can't because of the accusing look in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then how do you know it's his... birthday?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He told me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He speaks German?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he told you it's his birthday? The girl nods firmly as do the other children.  The boy watches it all, wide-eyed.  Helmut figures to put an end to this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What date is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, it's his birthday! This is too much for Helmut to fathom.  He turns his head away, trying to think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you believe him? Helmut turns back to them, looking first at the girl, then at the boy, his little upturned tear-stained face full of wonder.  Helmut softens, recalling perhaps his own birthday disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, I do. (pats boy's head) Tell him I wish him a happy birthday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He knows that.  But... but what're you going to do about a present? Helmut fans his clothes, finds the harmonica and produces it with a flourish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aha, the very thing.  He can be the clown while I'm gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Helmut bows and holds out the harmonica to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Happy birthday. The boy looks solemnly at Helmut and the harmonica.  He doesn't quite seem to understand what this is all about, but the harmonica is enticing.  He looks up at his countrymen for encouragement.  They smile at him, and he takes the harmonica, examines it, then blows into it experimentally. When he hears the SOUND that comes out, he brightens.  Then the little girl with the rag doll comes forward and offers it to the boy.  He looks at her strangely, one of the older German boys scoffs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a boy!  Dolls are for girls. The little girl is hurt, and looks to Helmut for support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you give something you love... it doesn't matter if it's the right thing. He takes the doll and puts one of it's hands in the boy's hand, the other in the little girl's.  They stand looking at each other and sharing the doll.  Helmut looks towards the door apprehensively, but there seems to be no action outside -- and there are the eyes of the children on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe we have time for a birthday game.  A quick one.  Let me take a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut goes back to the door.  He glances around outside. There still seems to be time.  He returns to the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody line up behind me now, and I'll show you how a train goes. Wait -- the harmonica. Helmut looks around for the new owner of the harmonica.  He goes over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I borrow it back... for just a minute or two? The boy studies him dubiously with that "Indian-giver" look in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For just a minute -- then I'll give it right back to you. (trying a sort of sign language) Just for the game. Finally the boy hands over the harmonica and manages a smile because he sees all the other children smiling at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  Now everybody...  line up behind me. The children scramble into line behind him.  Helmut looks back at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grab hold of the one in front of you...  'cause we're going to be a fast express train. The children, laughing and giggling, grab hold of one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All aboard.  All aboard. He puts the harmonica to his lips and begins huffing and puffing on it, imitating a train.  He begins to shuffle his feet and move slowly down the side of the car... the children holding on for dear life and following him... their eyes shining with expectation as Helmut begins to quicken his pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dim shafts of light from the two small square vent openings near the top on each side, gives the boxcar an eerie look. Helmut stops abruptly as he hears the slamming of the door. The children pile up behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! He moves quickly to the door and tugs at it.  Finding it locked, he pounds on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open the door!  Let me out...  LET ME OUT! But the train NOISES drown his voice.  Then the boxcar suddenly lurches and starts to move forward.  Helmut's pounding weakens and stops.  He turns from the door, his face reflecting his fright.  The children, not quite understanding what has happened, gather around him, and pull on him.  He manages to control his fear, and looking at the children, he manages a big smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guess I'm going with you after all. He switches on the lantern and holds it high so its rays cover all the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's play some more, Doork? Helmut glances down at the tot, started by the suggestion. Then he nods in a stunned sort of way.  He puts the harmonica to his mouth and begins puffing on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Scharff and Sergeant Hoffman stand watching the boxcar move away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TWO SHOT - SCHARFF, HOFFMAN SCHARFF I'm glad that's over.  Call in the sentries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. He starts to move away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kessler in the car?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kessler?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clown?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I... I guess he is, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You GUESS! Scharff races to the car with Sergeant Hoffman right behind him. The CAMERA FOLLOWS them. Scharff peers inside and finds the car empty.  With an angry glance at Hoffman, he hurries to the truck and looks in the cab.  It too is empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you to get him off the train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told him, sir.  HE was standing right by the door.  I'm sure he got off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you see him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, I...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You told me to see that the car was coupled on.  When I came back... Why wouldn't he get off?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Idiot! (shouting) Guards.  GUARDS! The other soldiers come running from o.s.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The clown prisoner is missing.  He may have escaped.  Search the area. If he got off the train he must be around here someplace. The soldiers rush o.s. into the deepening darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: TWO SHOT - SCHARFF, HOFFMAN SCHARFF You know what happens if he gets away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't get very far. Scharff looks o.s. after the disappearing train.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he's on that train -- he's going farther than you know --- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rear of the boxcar is just disappearing from sight in the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... or he knows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is the next morning.  Light is coming from the vents and the lantern which hangs from a peg in the middle of the right side of the car.  Helmut is asleep on the floor with the children huddled around him.  He lies on his side with one arm thrown protectively over the little Czech girl, Inga, and Willie.  Behind him, the Czech birthday boy and the girl with the doll are cuddled close to him.  Other youngsters have their heads on his legs and feet, and all are as close to him as they can get. He is, in fact, a sort of human bed.  From the train NOISES o.s. we can tell that the freight train is slowing down. Then, with a jolt, it stops, and o.s. we HEAR a truck engine approaching.  Helmut stirs and sits up, trying to get his bearings.  This arouses some of the children and they too sit up and look around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?  Are we there, Doork? Where are we?  Why are we stopping?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. He untangles himself, rises and stretches his numbed arms and legs.  He starts toward the door, but it slides open suddenly and a BURLY GUARD vaults inside.   Behind him we see a truck similar to a moving van being backed up to the boxcar.  Helmut blinks uncertainly at the light pouring through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody up.  No noise. The children are too startled to move.  The guard notices Helmut and reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the hell are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How the devil did you get in here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'm from the other prison.  Got locked in -- by accident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, for... (shouting out the door) Sergeant!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see now that the train has stopped at an isolated siding. The truck has backed up almost to the door of the boxcar.  A SERGEANT climbs down from the cab of the van and hurries to the boxcar door, the CAMERA PANNING him there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at this.  He's from the other camp.  Got in here with the shipment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did that happen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I was taking care of the children back there and... accidentally got locked in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of all the... What's your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork.  Helmut Doork. The Sergeant fumes for a moment, then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Put him in the truck with the others. And, let's get going.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the door as the Sergeant disappears.  Reaching out, the Burly Guard lowers the tailgate of the truck so that it forms a bridge to the boxcar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right, in the truck, quick now! The children, most of whom are on their feet now, hesitate, looking to Helmut for guidance.  The guard seizes one youngster and shoves him toward the door.  Instead, however, the child flies to Helmut and grabs him around the legs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said move!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait.  Let me. (to the children) Everybody up.  Come on.  Up, up, up. He moves around, helping the still seated children to their feet.  When they're all up...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you want me to stay with them? They'll be frightened without me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not for long, they won't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough.  Get them inside and keep them quiet. Burly guard starts to prod the children but they don't move, their eyes are fixed on Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do as he says.  And, don't worry, I'll be with you soon.  I promise. Reluctantly, the children march off.  They look back frequently at Helmut who waves to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come along, now. They walk over to a two-story building.  Helmut looks back in the direction of the children, then looks about the camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is just another prison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd you expect?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought the children were going to a better place. The Sergeant, with an incredulous look on his face, stares at Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cell is a small, bare cubicle containing only a cot and an open toilet.  In the wall, fronting on the prison yard, there is a small barred window.  Helmut stops pacing and moves over to it, and looks out.  The CAMERA SWINGS so that it is SHOOTING PAST Helmut's head through the window.  At the far end of the yard we can see the windowless stone buildings.  As Helmut stares out at them, we HEAR approaching footsteps. Helmut stiffens, turns toward the door as the SOUND of the footsteps grows louder and louder. The CAMERA SWINGS toward the door as it opens to reveal CAPTAIN CURT RUNKEL, a slender, impeccably groomed and thoroughly Nazified officer of the elite S.S.  He is the embodiment of all Hitlerian ideals.  Runkel strides into the cell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close the door, and wait out there. Guard closes the door.  Runkel studies Helmut coldly.  Without taking his eyes off Helmut, he pulls out a cigarette case, takes out cigarette, lights it and slowly inhales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a remarkable man.  Very remarkable. Helmut stirs uneasily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you any idea where you are? Helmut shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Auschwitz.  This is Auschwitz. (a beat) Mean anything to you? (before Helmut can answer) You may have observed we're enlarging our facilities. He moves over to the window and looks out, puffing slowly on his cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Still a great deal of work to be done. (proudly) It's going to be our most efficient, most modern prison. (he turns and smiles) And, I might add, most unique. (walks back towards Helmut, studying him carefully)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, you are a remarkable man.  I always wonder about remarkable men. (then evenly) Why did you come here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I explained.  I got locked in the boxcar and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, yes.  An accident.  Unavoidable I suppose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was taking care -- I mean, the Commandant requested me to take care of the children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commandant! Runkel tosses his cigarette on the floor and very deliberately grinds it out with his boot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've spoken to YOUR Commandant.  He hs you listed as an escaped prisoner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Escaped!  But...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... it was an accident. (his face close to Helmut's) Are you one of them, clown?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... no!  I'm not one of them.  I'm not ! Runkel smiles, moves away from Helmut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You misunderstand completely.  The Judas goat is never killed.  He isn't worth killing. (moves to cell door) I'm just asking you to lead them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His eyes plead, "No.  I can't do it.  No."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not... even to save your own life? For a brief moment, Helmut struggles to find the courage to stand up to Runkel -- but he has no courage and he sinks slowly to his knees, his head bowed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (victorious) I'm glad to see you're not a self- appointed martyr.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Runkel towers above Helmut who sits back on his haunches, leaning against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just think!  Now you're really one of us. The truth of Runkel's remark hits Helmut like a devastating blow.   He turns his face to the wall in shame.  Runkel walks to the door, raps on it, the guard outside swings it open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir... Sir... could I... could I have a little time with them before ... before... His voice trails off.  Runkel looks at Helmut while he thinks it over.  He moves back to the middle of the cell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.  Yes, of course. (he looks at his watch) I can give you about half an hour. (a little smile lights his face) You see, we're not heartless men here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the door as Helmut and the Sergeant approach from o.s.  Helmut has freshened his make-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember what I told you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There won't be any trouble. Helmut goes to the door and starts to open it.  The CAMERA MOVES UP to -- CLOSE SHOT - HELMUT With a great effort, he composes himself and throws open the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the door, where Helmut stands wearing an enormous grin.  The children are about the barren room in little groups.  When they see Helmut, they leap up and run to him, clinging to him as he closes the door behind him and moves into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork, Doork, you came back.  You came back.  We thought you'd left us.  Don't leave us, Doork. The children continue to ad lib expressions of mingled fear and delight at his return.  Helmut goes among them, patting their heads comfortingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There.  There.  It's all right. It's all right.   Everything is going to be all right. When the youngsters are calmed, Helmut holds up his hands for silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I want everyone to put on a big smile and sit down, because we're going to have more fun than we've ever had. Slowly, still unconvinced that they have nothing to fear, the children sit on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.  We'll start by seeing that we all have our names on our heads. The children begin to lower their heads so Helmut can check to see if their names are still there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes.  There's Fritz, Maria, Sadie, Inga, Josef, Nathan, Helga, Willie... The little girl with the rag doll holds up the doll for Helmut to see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, yes, Frederika!  Good.  I see all of your names. This is almost too much for Helmut, but he manages to control himself by turning away for a beat.  Then he turns back to the children, his big smile back in place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now... on with the show.  Just watch this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their little faces are troubled, worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a half hour later, and now the children are laughing at something Helmut is doing o.s.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK to -- MED. SHOT - THE GROUP Helmut is walking an imaginary tightrope.  Every few steps he almost loses his balance, but with comical gyrations he manages to complete the walk.  He bows deeply to the children -- and falls flat on his face.  The youngsters laugh, applaud and squeal delightedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helmut is lying on the floor near the boy.  He looks up at the tot and grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doork!  Doork... you're great ! Helmut grabs Willie and holds him close while he fights back his tears.   Willie plants a big kiss on his cheek.  Helmut scrambles to his feet, the CAMERA PULLING BACK to -- WIDER ANGLE SHOOTING PAST Helmut to the door as it opens, revealing the Sergeant, his face expressionless.  Helmut reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a few more minutes? The sergeant shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll bring them. The children are watching him, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter, Doork?  Where are we going?  You come with us this time.  Where're they taking us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They... they want us to move to another building... where we'll have more room... to play. (a beat) Tell you what.  Let's make it a big circus parade.  Everybody get in a line behind... He picks up Willie and stands him near the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... behind Willie here. The children scramble up and begin forming a line behind the very proud Willie.  Helmut looks around for the boy with the harmonica.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, where's our band?  The harmonica? He sees the boy and goes to him.  Helmut pantomimes playing the harmonica and points to himself.  The boy smiles widely, fishes the harmonica out of his pocket and holds it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There we are?  Everybody ready? Here we go. Helmut takes his place at the head of the line, like the Pied Piper, leads the youngsters out the door, playing a crude sort of circus parade music.  The little children giggle excitedly as they troupe out.  The older ones seem less certain, but as long as Helmut is with them, they feel secure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the procession of youngsters emerges from the barracks with Helmut dancing along at its head.  The Sergeant and the other two Guards stand watching in disbelief as the line turns and moves along toward the first of the windowless buildings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They look at each other incredulously.  What they are seeing surpasses their imagination.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: from a HIGH ANGLE as the procession moves toward the CAMERA.  Helmut looks back at his charges from time to time, smiling and waving and always puffing away on the harmonica.  The children smile back, some timidly and some a bit fearfully, but all smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in on the children as they march behind Helmut. We see some of them strutting, their little arms swinging freely.  Some of the little ones have to skip to keep up with the others.  They are all smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With each step, Helmut looks about, his eyes searching heaven, praying for the miracle that will save the children... the sudden blast of thunder, the striking down of the guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they follow the parade warily, almost as if expecting a trick.  They wear scowls worn into their faces by long use.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - HELMUT'S POV Its steel door gapes open.  Through the open doorway we can see a bare room in which what appears to be shower heads jutting from the wall.  A single ceiling light gives the room a stark appearance.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK and UP as the procession comes up toward the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Despair fills his eyes as he realizes that there is to be no miracle.  He looks ahead into the room, his courage fails him and he stops so abruptly that the children behind him run into his legs.  He turns and looks at them, then back to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Almost reluctantly, Helmut stands aside.  He tries to smile, but the result is almost grotesque.  He tries to speak, but no words come.  The Sergeant and the guard drift up toward him, scowling.  Gently, Helmut tousles the hair of little Willie and steers him through the door into the room.  The other children follow him hesitantly.  Helmut puts the harmonica to his lips and begins playing again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their clothes!  They've got to undress. The sergeant starts to move toward the line of children, the Sergeant grabs his arm and stops him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave them alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: over Helmut's shoulder down at the children as they file past him.  Each one hesitates a beat before him and looks up at him. Their faces are wondering, but trusting.  They smile tentatively.  Only the little girl with the doll hangs back, waiting for something rather than fearful of entering.  When all of the other children have gone in, she goes up to Helmut and wordlessly holds out her hand in a silent request to enter with him.  In her eyes is the absolute certainty that he will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LITTLE GIRL'S POV He looks down at her hand for a long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little girl waits for Helmut, but he doesn't take her hand.  Shyly, she begins to withdraw it.  Suddenly, Helmut reaches out and grabs her hand, clutching it desperately as he needs her innocence to control the panic that is tearing at him.  Holding on to her to steady himself, they walk together into the room, the CAMERA PANNING with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to the door as Helmut and little girl enter.  Suddenly, the door slams shut behind them.  Helmut whirls to it instinctively, as if to shove it open or cry out for help, but he does neither.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His face is pressed against the steel door.  He fights the panic within him.  Then, he quickly wipes his eyes and turns back towards the children.  Slowly he takes three chunks of stale bread from his coat pocket and begins juggling them, at the same time waggling his head from side to side, slowly at first, then more gaily.  From deep inside him comes a tiny, tiny laugh.  The CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY to reveal the children in the f.g.  Suddenly, Helmut tosses the pieces of bread high, high into the air and stretches out his arms to encompass all the children.  As they gather around him, they take up his soft laugh, timidly at first, then more assuredly until the chamber resounds with gentle laughter.
direction.name: direction
